title: zelenskys defiant behaviour proves vladimir
story: Zelenskys defiant behaviour proves Vladimir Putin cannot win war in UkraineAs he addressed MPs in the House of Commons and talked about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky pointed out he was talking to everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world.Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky addressed MPs in the House of Commons via videolink Image: PAopinionByBrian Reade:,  Mar |commentsIn a political chamber that has too often witnessed cowardice here was the face of courage. You had to pinch yourself to realise that until very recently our Prime Minister spent every appearance here refusing to admithe’d held parties in his own flat. Yet here was the leader of a major European country being brutally honest about the devastating shelling of flats by an invading army in cities three hours away from the UK on a budget flight.As Volodymyr Zelensky outlined the crimes being unleashed by a “gangster state” the assembled MPs, wearing headphones and grim expressions on the packed benches, gave the big, hushed room the feel of a war crimes court. Hopefully a modern-day Nuremberg awaits Zelensky’s nemesis, Putin. The Ukrainian leader pointed out he was addressing everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world. And dressed in his trademark green tee-shirt he looked the part. As he gave us a breakdown of the horrors happening in his homeland, with eyes heavy and face drawn, it could have been someone you’d just met talking you through a personal tragedy. If anything encapsulates the Spirit of Ukraine it is this man. If anything says Putin won’t win it is Zelensky’s defiant demeanour. His presence in our parliament, like his message, was simple. It said: “I’m not hiding, I’m not afraid. We will endure.” Other world leaders have addressed Westminster before such as Barack Obama and Angela Merkel. But whereas they felt like they were taking part in some mutual admiration ceremony, this felt real. It felt urgent.  Whenever we turn our TVs on we see voiceless children and pensioners scrambling for their lives, and here was their voice. Here was their living symbol of resistance. Here was a man telling us, from the heart, why we cannot further abandon those innocent civilians who do not deserve their plight. Yet who do deserve our protection. It made you ashamed of the listening government’s pathetic response to the refugee crisis, with the pitul amount of visas they’ve handed out and the bureaucratic hoops they are making desperate people jump through to get them. Zelensky is what we hope we would all be when put under the most intolerable of pressure. Cool and courageous. This former actor is suddenly making speeches on the hoof that the finest dramatists would be proud of. For his British audience he evoked Shakespeare, saying there was no question of whether Ukraine’s fate was “to be or not to be.” It was to be. He pushed the British patriotic buttons even harder when he summoned the spirit of Winston Churchill, vowing to fight the Russian enemy in the fields and in the forests. Johnson gave a knowing smile of recognition when he heard that. Priti Patel sat there smirking by his side throughout, as she does. And when Zelensky talked about dramatically increasing sanctions, Rishi Sunak’s eyebrows twitched as he did the sums.  To hear him speak is to realise how badly Putin underestimated the will of Ukrainians. It’s the sense of calm he projects that has kept his nation going in the face of horrendous oppression. At the end of his -minute speech, during a long standing ovation, some MPs wiped away tears. It was a moving performance which humbled all who watched and gave us hope. Because the longer Zelensky survives and the more he draws standing ovations from parliaments and wet cheeks from millions watching on TV, the more he becomes Putin’s worst nightmare. title: my mum picked out date
story: Exclusive: My mum picked out my date weeks before she died - now I know hes The OneWhen Laura McNally partnered with charity Marie Curie at work, she was struck by the incredible support they offered to people at the end of their lives - but she never knew how much shed end up needing them herselfLaura started dating Peter after her mum encouraged her to message him Image: Laura McNallyByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsBased in London and with a successful marketing career, Laura McNally was living le “in the fast lane.” The now -year-old had spent more than a decade living in the capital after moving from her hometown of Cookstown, Northern Ireland. She’d been working for supermarket chain Spar and had been given responsibility for its partnership with the charity Marie Curie. “My role was to promote the partnership in Spar stores,” Laura tells The Mirror. And while she worked closely with the charity in her career, she never had any idea how its nurses would end up touching her le.When the first coronavirus lockdown came into effect, Laura decided to move back to Cookstown to look after her parents, who were struggling with poor health.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Her dad Emmet had been suffering from ongoing heart problems, while her mum Ailish was battling bowel cancer. “I thought, ‘They’re going to need help’. I worried for them. Dad had been poorly for a number of years, and at the time my mum was going through chemo,” she explains. Emmet and Ailish, who had met when they were just  years old, had been married for more than three decades and were an inspiration to Laura. “I grew up with a modest childhood but it was a happy le. It wasn’t filled with big extravagant things,” she says. Laura describes her dad, who worked as a taxi driver, as someone who “lit up a room.” She says: “My dad was very down to earth. He loved le. He had a huge big smile and his laugh was contagious.”  Good with advice, Emmet’s taxi was likened to a confession box because his passengers often confided in him. “He’d never tell us anything though. He knew everything everyone was doing in town but he kept it to himself,” Laura says. But while he never gossiped about others, Laura says her dad often gushed about his daughter to passengers. “I’d come home and people would know all about me - he’d talk about me all the time. I think he was proud of me,” she says. Despite his lust for le, Emmet’s physical health was declining and he’d suffered from heart problems for several years. When Laura moved back to Cookstown she knew he would need help looking after Ailish while she had chemotherapy.  She describes her mum as the “rock who held everything together” in the family. “She loved to travel - I think that’s where I get my adventurous streak from,” Laura says. “She was more like a friend sometimes, I’d have told her anything.” Growing up holding her parents in such high regard, Laura says it was dficult to see them in ailing health - but she cherished the time she spent with them during lockdown. In the summer of  Emmet’s health took a turn for the worse and he ended up in hospital. “He started to really deteriorate and he was in the hospital for nearly three months,” Laura recalls.  “He was in and out of ICU so I told the doctors thatthis was only going in one direction I’d prefer to have him at home. He was such a homely man.” At the end of August, Emmet was brought back to the family home where he was visited by Marie Curie nurses every day. “He was such a proud Irishman, and even in his last days those nurses helped him keep his dignity,” Laura recalls. “To be that vulnerable with your we and daughter in the room is hard, but they supported him with a pain-free ending. They made sure he was really comfortable.” Emmet sadly passed away on  September  at just  years old. Although Laura and Ailish were devastated, they were grateful for the support the nurses had given them during his last days. As Emmet was laid to rest, Ailish and Laura came together with her three brothers to give him as traditional a funeral as they could while social distancing rules were in place.  And while Laura drew strength from a supportive family, the next few months were tough for her and her mum - who was still battling cancer. “We originally found out mum had cancer after she’d visited my oldest brother in Australia,” Laura recalls. “She got pains in her stomach and they thought it was appendicitis, so she had an operation while she was out there. “But when she got home she had a follow-up. She was diagnosed with bowel cancer and it was stage .” Laura says Ailish had a few successful operations to clear ious tumours, but over the years the cancer had continued to spread. By the time Laura had gone home to see her parents during lockdown, Ailish’s care was palliative.  And just months after Emmet’s death, Ailish and Laura received the news they were dreading. Laura recalls: “We sat down with the consultant on Zoom at the end of February and he said the cancer was spreading. My mum asked how long she had and he replied, ‘You’ve got until Easter’. “Mum had just celebrated her th birthday and she looked well. She didn’t look like someone who was dying of cancer. “I said to the consultant, ‘Do you know when Easter is  It’s only six weeks away’. And he said, ‘Yeah, six weeks’.” From that moment on, Laura says she went into “autopilot,” thinking only of her mum.  “Everything I did was for her. She was my priority,” Laura says. As Ailish began to deteriorate, she and Laura began to talk openly about how she wanted her le to end. “We talked about her potentially going into a hospice but we have a huge family, and with Covid restricting visitors, we decided it was best for her to be at home,” Laura says. “She deteriorated slowly, but the Marie Curie nurses helped her too. Mum knew she was dying and the fear and anxiety were very tough for us all.” Laura recalls the nurses arriving at the family home to take care of Ailish and askingthey had the wrong address - because they’d only been there nine months before caring for Emmet. But she doesn’t know how she’d have got through it all without their support.  “They were like walking angels,” she says. Meanwhile, Laura devoted all her time to be with her mum and refused to leave her side. She says: “People had to force me to go to bed. I didn’t want to sleep because I thoughtI slept, that was less time I’d have with mum.” In the last weeks of her le, Ailish laughed and joked with her daughter as they had always done - and even had fun talking about Laura’s love le. “Mum was in bed a lot and we’d be up all hours talking about my future and what my wedding day would be like.“It must have been am and I was on Facebook Dating. We came across a guy called Peter and mum said, ‘Message him, he looks lovely’.”After following her mum’s advice, Laura got chatting to Peter, who was also from Cookstown, and soon after he asked her out on a date.“I was reluctant to go on a date,” Laura recalls. “Mum was my priority and I worried something would happen while I was out.” But friends and family convinced Laura to go, arguing she needed to do something for herself. And after spending a few hours on a walk with Peter, Laura realised she’d made the right decision. The pair realised they’d both lived fairly close by in London for years - and their paths had almost crossed several times before. Although the pair clicked instantly, Laura was keen to get home to see Ailish after a few hours - but she said Peter was understanding from the beginning. “He stuck by me and understood - most guys wouldn’t,” she said. Over the next days and weeks, Peter checked in with Laura every single day - eventhe pair hadn’t seen each other. Sadly, on  June , Ailish passed away at home - and less than a year after losing her dad, Laura had to plan her mum’s funeral too.  Once again, her tight-knit family rallied around to support her while she grieved - and this time, Laura had Peter to lean on too. “He came to the wake and was introduced to everyone - my whole family was there,” Laura says. “When I came back to the house after the funeral and everyone had gone, there was just silence. It’s probably the worst feeling I’ve ever had in my whole le. That’s when the grief takes over. “But Peter was there for me.” After losing both her parents in a short space of time, Laura began to re-evaluate things in her le and made some big decisions. She decided to quit her job and set up her own marketing company, giving herself the freedom to work whenever and wherever she wanted - and fitting in Peter’s work around that. “I live le very dferently now,” Laura says. “I wake up now and it hits me every day like a ton of bricks. But I have a choice: I can stay in bed all day or I can get up and do something positive every day, evenit’s something little.  “Don’t get me wrong, I still have down days, but I think, ‘what would my parents thinkthey were watching me now’ ” As Laura and Peter navigate a new way of living their lives, Laura is keen to encourage people to talk about their grief - admitting that telling people about what her parents were like is incredibly cathartic for her. “Over the last two years during the pandemic, so many more people have lost loved ones,” she says. Laura adds it’s important to acknowledge those we have lost - and she’s taking part in Marie Curie’s National Day of Reflection on  March to honour them. While le is ing to some kind of normal as Covid restrictions are lted, the charity wants to acknowledge those who are still grappling with grief after losing people during the pandemic. It will hold a minute’s silence at midday in tribute to those who died and will also be hosting a Wall of Reflection. For Laura, who holds the charity close to her heart, the day will provide some comfort as she remembers Emmet and Ailish.Do you have a love story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcShe says: “Before I lost my parents I used to thinksomeone lost a loved one you shouldn’t talk about it for fear of upsetting them. “But now,I get an opportunity, I talk about them. I miss them loads and I love them to bits.” To find out more about the National Day of Reflection on  March, please visit mariecurie.org.uk dayofreflection To support the Great Daffodil Appeal this month, please visit: mariecurie.org.uk Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveBowel cancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: binge eater spends 9000 dream
story: Binge eater spends £, on dream body after living a letime on fad dietsAmy Elsley, , from Rainham, East London, used to keep eating until she felt sick but now after big changes to her le she says she is a better mum and her le is betterA large part of Amy Elsleys stomach was removed ten months ago - and the surgery totally transformed her le Image: amys.sleeved.le   MERCURY PRESSByLucy NotarantonioSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar |comments A binge eater who spent £,k to get her le back on track says she is now a better mum after spending a letime on fad diets . Amy Elsley, , began dieting aged  but struggled to maintain a healthy weight.She says it caused her to become severely depressed as she turned to food for comfort. The scenic artist weighed st lbs at her heaviest - and decided she had to do something about it. The mum-of-one from Rainham, East London, found it hard to stop eating once she started, until she decided to undergo surgery in May . A large part of Amyaposs stomach was removed for £, last year and she says its the best decision she has ever made.Now, ten months on, Amy is st lbs and couldnapost be happier. She said: I have always been a yo-yo dieter but it didnapost matter how much I lost as I would always put double back on. Eventually, I grew sick and tired of my reflection. I was ashamed and disgusted that I had let myself get to the weight I was at.I knew I needed an extra bit of help which is why I opted for a gastric sleeve. Amy used to eat large portions and McDonaldaposs frequently for her lunch. She recalls skipping meals such as breakfast and to compensate binged during the evening.But at the start of , Amy was signed off work with depression. She adds: I would never eat breakfast but once I started to eat, I could never stop. It was like I wouldnapost give myself chance to feel full. Iaposd just keep on eating until I felt like I was going to be sick. Iaposd typically order nine chicken nuggets, a double cheese burger, large fries and cheese melts from McDonaldaposs for my lunch. Then Iaposd always have a huge portion of stodgy dinner. My weight and appearance combined with the lockdown made me feel so depressed. I wasnapost showering for days nor leaving my bed as I had hit a really low point in my le. I wasnapost able to be the mum my daughter Evie, five, deserves which is what prompted me to make the call to Spire London East Hospital.  Within two months, I was on the table ready for the surgery. Amy used her le savings to fund the surgery - and now insists it was worth every penny as she feels like a new woman. She adds: I havenapost got one regret. I finally have my le back. When I was overweight, I was a recluse and I couldnapost wear the clothes I like. I wouldnapost even put makeup on as I didnapost want to draw any kind of attention to myself. Itaposs so hard when you are big to feel accepted as people constantly judge you. But now I am like a completely dferent person. I am a better mum to Evie and the first to go down the slide with her or on a ride. Previously, I was too ashamed and embarrassed in case I got stuck. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Amy insists weight loss surgery isnapost the aposeasyapos option. She adds: I think there is a stigma around surgery, but itaposs not the easy way out. I would have loved to spend £k on something  but it was important to me and my only option. It feels like I have finally stepped out of a fat persons costume. I feel amazing and so much more relaxed in social settings now. I still have to keep an eye on what I am eating but I am making much healthier choices now. The surgery was a le changing decision which requires work I have to hit protein goals daily. Food diary before: Breakfast - skip Lunch - McDonalds - nine nuggets, double cheese burger, large fries, diet coke and cheese melts Dinner - Large portion of spaghetti Bolognese Food diary now: Breakfast - Two Belvita breakfast biscuits or small porridge Lunch - Caesar salad Dinner - Meat and vegetables Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsMental healthGastric bandsWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: britains loneliest lion could moved
story: Britains loneliest lion could be moved from his home after second playmate diesBailey has been left all alone after his -year-old cousin Naja was put down last week following a rapid deterioration in her healthBailey is alone now after his cousins died Image: Shanice Moore   SWNS.COMByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A lion thought to be Britainaposs loneliest could be relocated from his home of  years to be with lionesses, after losing his second female companion in just two years.Bailey the lion has been king of the pride at Colchester Zoo in Essex since  when he arrived with his cousins Naja and Malika. But Bailey has been left all alone, after -year-old Naja was put down last week following a rapid deterioration in her health. It comes less than  months after the pair lost Malika in October , at the age of . Now, staff at Colchester Zoo are keeping a close eye on lonely Bailey and are even considering relocating him to another zoo with a pride of lionesses.  In a statement issued on their website earlier this week, zoo staff wrote: We would like to thank all our visitors for the overwhelming support that we have received following the devastating news of the passing of our female lioness, Naja, on Friday, March . We have received many kind messages towards our staff, as well as concerns about our male lion, Bailey. Bailey’s health and welfare is our top priority and, whilst our Animal Care Team continues to monitor him daily, discussions have been put in place by the Animal Care Management Team regarding Bailey’s future at Colchester Zoo. The team are currently exploring bringing in a female lioness for Bailey, but this option is reliant on a lioness being available at one of our neighbouring zoos. However, given Bailey’s age, introducing a female at this stage in his le could prove too stressful. The team are also exploring relocating Bailey to another zoo with a pride of lionesses. This would be dependent on another organisation having the space to house Bailey and the move alone could prove too much. Bailey has become a big part of the Colchester Zoo family and parting with him feels almost impossible and irresponsible. Read more Our Animal Care Team will continue to monitor Bailey’s mental and physical welfare over the next few weeks. It’s our responsibility to ensure that Bailey’s welfare is at the forefront of any decision made, which may include letting him live out the rest of his le here at the zoo by himself. A previous statement last week paid tribute to Naja, writing: Naja was truly one of a kind. Her personality and character set her aside from any other animal we’ve had the pleasure to work with. Naja had a gentle side where she would interact with her keepers, but very quickly changed when food was available! Not only will all the staff at Colchester Zoo miss Naja, but she also leaves behind our male lion, Bailey. Bailey and Naja were cousins along with Naja’s sister, Malika, who passed away back in . All three lions had a strong bond, with the bond between Bailey and Naja made even stronger with the loss of Malika. title: dad 47 attend living wake
story: Dad, , will attend his own living wake as one of two dying wishesGordon Airlie was diagnosed with Acute myeloid leukaemia at Ninewells Hospital in April  and initially told he likely had just -hours to liveGordon, , and Audrey Airlie, , from DundeeByKaitlin EastonReporter:,  Mar |commentsA terminally-ill father delivered the devastating news that he had just weeks left to live, has now organised his own “living wake”.Gordon Airlie was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia at Ninewells Hospital in April  and initially told he likely had just -hours to live.The -year-old had suffered from recurring sickness, body pain and blood blisters and had noticed blood in his urine and faeces.The dad fought on, with things looking up as he received a stem cell donation at the end of the year. However, the aggressive cancer ed and at the beginning of this month Gordon was told he likely had just weeks to live,The Daily Recordreports.Gordon, from Dundee, had two dying wishes - to marry partner of -years Audrey, , and host a living wake for himself.  Initially both events were planned for March  but doctors advised the family to move the wedding forward and within  hours they had planned the event at their family home. Step-daughter Kirsty McLean, , said: We got the blood test results on Friday and doctors said the disease was progressing fast and he might not make it to the wedding. Within  hours we had organised a wedding to happen at the house. We were running all over town trying to arrange everything and get cakes. We decorated the house and stuff as well with balloons. It was just close family and friends that attended. Weaposre now planning his living wake at the moment and waiting on another blood test to see how much the cancer has progressed.I had personally never heard of a living wake before and didnapost know it was a thing but he wants to get all his pals together one last time to say goodbye. The living wake is currently planned for March  at Gordonaposs favourite local, Club  in Dundee, but the family expect they will need to bring the event forward again. A band has been booked for the entertainment and a photo booth and photographer have been booked to capture precious memories. Loved ones will also be encouraged to write down their favourite memories with Gordon to share at the special event.  Gordon, who is step-dad to Kirsty, Tami and Dana, and dad to Kerr, is also hoping to have a final outing with his grandchildren. I donapost know how Iaposll manage at the wake, all my sisters and I have done is cry, Kirsty said. We are all just in so much shock - we couldnapost believe it - because he did get the all clear in January. My mum is one of the strongest women Iaposve ever met. Itaposs just her there on her own trying to do everything for him so I think it will really hit her after. Dave Mack from Club said they would make sure Gordon, nicknamed Googs, had a very special evening. Googs is a very well respected member of the Club and dart team,” he said. “Heaposs a good friend of mine as well and has been here for years as a leader of the darts team. For his living wake we will assist his family and make sure we give him something very special. He is such a great guy - he popped in the other week to see everyone and the club was full of people wanting to hi. Weaposre going to pull out all the stops for him to give him a great farewell. The family have scraped together so they could pay for the last minute wedding and are currently paying for the wake with their own cash. Tami has launched a fundraising page to go towards the cost of the wake as leftover cash will go to Gordonaposs final outing with his grandchildren.Donations to the page can be madehere .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsCancerLeukaemia" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news delta-omicron-covid-hybrid-detected-"Stealth Omicron: What is the BA. iant BySam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar |comments A Delta-Omicron coronavirus hybrid has been detected in the UK as experts warn the government it shouldnapost be ignored. Dubbed ‘Deltacron’, the new French-based strain combines both lineages. However, its severity is not yet known.But there is a warning that immunity is waning in the elderly as one scientist added that it is aposthe real thingapos. The World Health Organisation said it is apostracking and discussingapos the iant following research into the strain. There is no clear data yet to show whether Deltacron is more infectious than its predecessors. Health chiefs told The Sun a very small number of cases have been detected in Britain, but more details are to be reported in a briefing on Friday.Aris Katzourakis, professor of evolution and genomics at the University of Oxford, said: “It is one to keep an eye on. This one is legit. Dr Stephen Grfin, a virologist at the University of Leeds, said: “Whilst it doesn’t seem to have taken off as a dominant strain yet, this could be due to a very slow start based upon seeding density - the number of initial cases, he said.“There are multiple scenarios that can play out here in terms of what this means for people that become infected as this combination of viral proteins may behave dferently to either parent. “The French cluster appears to be a validated occurrence where a recombination event has given rise to a virus fit enough to circulate.Last month, the UK Health Security Agency announced it was investigating a iant named “Delta x Omicron Recombinant ”.However, it is not knownthis is linked to the French-based Deltacron.  Hospitalisation in the UK have shown an aposuptickapos in the past fortnight, data shows. The ZOE Covid Symptom Study estimates around , people are catching Covid each day - a  per cent hike in one week. Study co-founder Professor Tim Spector said: “The ‘official’ UK dashboard rate that continues to provide a misleading picture of the pandemic in the UK and should be scrapped. “The major increase in new cases across the country and in the elderly is a worry, especially as we now see an uptick in hospitalisations for the first time. “This increase was predicted when all restrictions were lted. “We are likely to continue to see high infection and prevalence rates of  in  people for the foreseeable future.” Dr Jenny Harries, head of the UKHSA, said: “The increasing presence of the BA. sub-lineage of Omicron and the recent slight increase in infections in those over  show that the pandemic is not over and that we can expect to see Covid circulating at high levels.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON University of OxfordCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dock worker who held martial
story: Worker fired for teaching martial arts class while bed-bound with spine injuryMichael Connorton had been off work for more than four months when his bosses were given a tip-off that he was instructing Hapkido classesMichael Connorton at Teesside Hapkido, in Middlesbrough Image: Evening GazetteByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A dockyard worker was sacked after his bosses hired private investigators and caught him teaching martial arts classes while he was off work injured, a tribunal heard.Michael Connorton told his managers he was in so much pain after suffering a spinal injury that all he could do was lay in bed or on his sofa. But after the port worker had been off work for more than four months, his bosses were given a tip-off that he was instructing Hapkido classes. The bosses at PD Ports hired private investigators to carry out aposcovert surveillanceapos on Mr Connorton - and were provided with photos and videos of him teaching the Korean martial art to a class of . The covert recordings showed him driving to class, adopting aposfighting stancesapos, wielding training swords, demonstrating combat moves and carrying heavy objects aposwithout obvious signs of discomfortapos.When the  year old was summoned to explain himself, he claimed he aposcouldnapost rememberaposhe attended any other classes while off injured because his medication gave him aposmemory lossapos. Mr Connorton was sacked for gross misconduct but has tried to sue PD Ports for disability discrimination - however now his case has been thrown out at an employment tribunal. Mr Connorton, who has been training in martial arts since he was , is a th Dan black belt in Hapkido and has won tournaments in the discipline. Alongside others he set up his own class about  years ago and now teaches at Hapkido Teesside in Middlesbrough. The tribunal, held in Newcastle, heard Mr Connorton worked for PD Ports, one of the UKaposs leading port groups operating  dock sites nationwide.  He was a dockyard worker at the companyaposs Teesport site on the River Tees, North Yorks, and worked for the firm since . The tribunal heard Mr Connorton was signed off sick in October  after suffering a aposspasm of painapos at work caused by a degenerative disc bulging from his spine. In February  he told Occupational Health - who visited him at home due to him claiming he was in too much pain to travel - that he was unable to do anything other than read, which he could do while lying on his bed or sofa. On February , Mr Connortonaposs bosses received a report he was aposactually teaching his martial arts classapos. The next day he told Occupational Health his pain had not improved, he could not drive and his symptoms were causing aposlow mood and fatigueapos. However, the same evening he drove to his martial arts class. The private investigators discovered he drove to and attended the Hapkido class on February ,  and  - and they filmed him on each visit. A tribunal report said:The investigators provided PD Ports with a report and photographs and a video recording. Amongst other things, the investigatorsapos report refers to Mr Connorton, without any obvious signs of discomfort or ailment, driving to and from the class. [It shows him] rising from the floor after conducting stretching exercises with a class of approximately  people, assisting with student development, lting a metal barrier and then a five-a-side football goal. [It shows him] carrying a number of training swords and walking approximately  metres carrying a large sports bag holstered over his right shoulder, providing instruction, contributing to martial arts activity instruction including adopting a fighting stance and shouting to all the class that he was about undertake aposmock testsapos for those who wanted to practice. The photographs are supportive of the above in that they show him arriving at the class driving himself in his car, walking without any apparent discomfort, carrying a bag and equipment and moving barriers and a football goal. In the class itself the claimant is shown wearing his Hapkido suit, exercising, conducting exercises, kneeling and demonstrating martial arts moves and techniques. In light of this report, PD Ports was concerned at the apparent disparity between what he was reporting and what he was doing, and that he was not being truthful. During a disciplinary process, Mr Connorton was shown the images but said he could not rememberhe had attended other classes between October  and February  aposdue to drugsapos. Mr Connorton said he was aposnot instructing but was showing and guiding othersapos, which the tribunal ruled was aposlittle more than semanticsapos. He claimed the items he carried were light and he went to the class to improve his mental health but was still in pain. He said he had not done anything aposstrenuousapos. He was sacked in March , with bosses citing apossignicant doubts with regard to your honesty and integrityapos. Employment Judge John Morris ruled the dismissal was fair and had nothing to do with him being disabled as a result of his injury. He said: The reason for [Mr Connortonaposs] dismissal was his lack of candour and frankness throughout the disciplinary process and his failure to provide a satisfactory explanation for his attendance at the Hapkido classes. The key point for [PD Ports] was the aposdisconnectapos between what he had said to Occupational Health on February  and the information from the surveillance team. title: dog nicknamed mr ugly searching
story: Dog nicknamed Mr Ugly searching for new home after being found alone on mountainFive-year-old Vincent has become known as Mr Ugly at Blind Dogs Rescue UK - but is hoping to shake his unfortunate nickname when he secures a new home in the UKVincent is searching for a new home Image: Blind Dog Rescue UKByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsAfter being nicknamed Mr Ugly, volunteers lost a little hope that this poor pooch will find his forever family.The five-year-old dog, who is completely blind, was taken in by Blind Dog Rescue UK after spending a year wandering alone on a mountainside.He was in a really bad way with hardly any fur on his body when he was picked up by the rescue. Actually called Vincent, the lonely dog is hoping somebody in the UK will come forward to offer in a place in their home. A spokesperson from Blind Dog Rescue UK said: Introducing the gorgeous Vincent who has the unfortunate nickname of Mr Ugly at the shelter.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.He is leishmania positive which caused his blindness and will need regular medication and blood tests for this for his entire le.Since being rescued from the mountains, Vincentaposs fur has completely grown back, meaning he can soon leave his Mr Ugly nickname behind. He has been described as a clam, sweet, and sociable dog who enjoys spending time with humans. New places and situations are stressful for him but he gets used to it quickly, said the spokesperson. In the shelter, he is dominant with other male dogs but he is friendly and playful with female dogs.Vincent would love a patient home where he can learn to trust his new family and can live with a female dog for company. Vincent is currently living in a rescue in Greece but is ready to fly to the UK once a family is found. Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.“These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. At this point, we are able to start assessing and promoting these wonderful dogs for forever homes.To adopt Vincent, or find out more information about him, contact Blind Dog Rescue UK via their website www.bdruk.org.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog no nose gets adopted
story: Exclusive: Dog with no nose gets adopted by loving family after being rescued from badger-baitingThree-year-old Patterdale terrier Riddle is learning how to play and cuddle after being adopted by a forever family from Dogs Trust Canterbury and saved from illegal badger-baitingThe little Patterdale terrier has found a warm home and a loving family after being rescued Image: Samantha DantonByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Mar |comments A dog with a missing nose who was rescued from badger-baiting has been adopted by a loving family, after his hunt for a home was shared on the . The three-year-old Patterdale terrier named Riddle was at Dogs Trust Canterbury, desperately waiting for someone to accept his unique appearance.Staff were in awe of his absolutely lovely personality and well manners - that later went on to win over his adoptive new owners, Samantha and David Danton, and their -year-old daughter, Evie. Rescuers believed the pup was forced to compete in an illegal blood sport due to his injured nose and scars on his legs.Samantha, , based in Clfsend, told The Mirror : He is fabulous and doesnapost have an ounce of aggression. He is so calm and just amazing.  to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Samantha and her family have been looking for a rescue dog since their miniature schnauzer passed away in March . She fell in love with Riddle when she spotted his little face online. It wasnapost necessarily the fact that he didnapost have a nose, but his poor face kept playing on my mind. He had been through so much, Samantha said. Two weeks ago, Samantha and David, , were invited to meet Riddle for the first time at Dogs Trust, then went again to take him for a walk with their daughter.He was very friendly and as soon as he saw us, he rolled over and let us tickle his tummy. He was incredibly welcoming, Samantha said. On Sunday  March, the family brought him home and changed his name to Ralphie. He was named Riddle after Voldemort because of his missing nose. We wanted to change his name to give him a fresh start in le, Samantha explained. Ralphie had never been inside a house before and found the sofa quite amusing at first. He kept trying to e down the back, Samantha said. We taught him how to play with toys and heaposs learning to bring balls in from the garden. Yesterday I was on my own with him and we had a cuddle. It was quite emotional. Despite his dferences in appearance, Riddle is just like any other dog and can still use his working nostrils. Phil Carter, the assistant manager at Dogs Trust Canterbury, said: His personality shines through.Do you have a dog story to share  Email nia.dalton@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimalsBadgers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news five-signs-charles-wants-repair-"Prince Harry offers continued support to those suffering in UkraineByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments One year has passed since Prince Harry and Meghan Markle sat down with Oprah Winfrey for a bombshell chat about their time as working royals. In it, they opened up about many members of the Firm - with Harry accusing his dad Prince Charles of cutting him off financially and not taking his calls. Even after the explosive chat, he appeared on the Armchair Expert podcast, where he lashed out at Charlesaposs parenting and talked about total neglect on the Apple TV series The Me You Canapost See. Later reports claimed that relations between the pair were at rock bottom - but recently there have been signs that Harry, Meghan and Charles could be ready to bury the hatchet. Here we take a look at them... Full of praise  One of the first signs that Harry and Charlesapos relationship could be improving was just a few days into . Charles wrote an essay for Newsweek, where he issued a call for urgent action to save the environment.In the piece, he praised both Prince William and Harry for their work in raising awareness of the issue. He spoke about how he was proud of both of his sons for having recognised the threat of climate change. He said: Most recently, my elder son, William, launched the prestigious Earthshot Prize to incentivise change and help repair our planet over the next ten years by identying and investing in the technologies that can make a dference. And my younger son, Harry, has passionately highlighted the impact of climate change, especially in relation to Africa, and committed his charity to being net-zero. Video calls Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . Shortly after the Newsweek essay was released, the Mirror revealed that Charles had held several “good-natured and enjoyable” video calls with Harry. Sources close to Charles said that despite reports of the two not speaking, Charles and Harry have been on “a journey of rediscovery” in terms of their relationship. One said: “The Prince of Wales has spoken to his son frequently in recent months. He loves him very much, as he does both his children, and he looks forward to them being able to spend time together in the near future.” Regular contact And it seems these video calls might not be a one-off for Harry and Charles and itaposs been suggested they talk regularly.Thataposs because, writing in the , royal expert Camilla Tominey claims that Prince Charles is thought to be in regular contact with his youngest son.However, she added: Whether Meghan will everto the UK remains to be seen. Olive branch invitation Meanwhile, it has also been reported that Charles offered his son an olive branch by offering him an invitation to stay with him the next time he brings his family to the UK.The offer of bringing the family together for the first time since Harry and Meghan decided to quit their royal roles and set up home in Calornia was made by the heir in the lead up to Christmas, it is understood. But Charles’s good-natured plan, in an attempt to heal the rt between him and his son, has been thrown into doubt after Harry suggested awould come at “too great a personal risk” due to his security situation. Meghanaposs photo Meanwhile, another sign came on Tuesday when eagle-eyed royal fans spotted a touching photo of Meghan Markle that has pride of place in Charles and the Duchess of Cornwallaposs home.Camilla welcomed three female rowers, who crossed the Atlantic in record time, to Clarence House - the London home she shares with Charles - to mark International Womenaposs Day. They were joined by former male rower Tim Christian and were pictured chatting with Camilla in a sitting room at the royal residence.  Behind where the guests were sitting, royal fans noticed a side table that was filled with lovely family photos. And one of them included a stunning black-and-white image of Meghan with Charles on her wedding day in . When Meghan married Harry, Charles escorted the bride halfway down the aisle of St Georgeaposs Chapel in Windsor - and the framed photo appears to depict this. title: how worried should new covid
story: How worried should we be about new Covid spike as cases surge by % in a weekInfections appear to be rising in over s as the BA. Omicron iant spreads, with experts sounding the alarm that the pandemic is not over yet despite Boris Johnsons Living with Covid plan London Overground" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _BRITAIN-TRANSPORT-RAIL-STRIKE.jpg" width"" "" Commuters, some wearing face coverings due to Covid-, exit a Transport for LondonLondon Overground Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar |commentsThe Covid pandemic is not over yet and the latest surge in cases is a concern, say experts.Infections appear to be rising in older people as socialising increases in the wake of Freedom Day last month, vaccine immunity wanes and BA. - a more transmissible Omicron strain - spreads.Although BA. is more contagious than BA., clinical data does not suggest a signicant dference in disease severity.Wednesday saw recorded infections rise by more than  percent and deaths by two thirds compared to last week, according to data from the Department of Health. Hospital admissions have also risen sharply, with , people in hospitals with the virus on March  and  requiring a mechanical ventilator.The worrying figures come just weeks before the government plans to scrap free lateral flow tests for most people on April .Are you worried by the rise  Have your say in the comment section Free PCR tests will also not be available to people with symptoms as the government implements its aposLiving with Covidapos plan, introduced on February . Data from a study by Imperial College’s React- team shows around one in  peoplein England were infected between February  and March  - with the virus particularly prevalent in people over . The figure was a drop on the . percent recorded between January  and , but was the second-highest rate since the study started in .  The React- data comes from nearly , swabs from homes across England. It shows infections have dropped since the January peak but scientists involved said the R value, or the average number of infected, remained below  for those  and under. But for those  and over it stood at .. Experts are investigating whether hospitalisation rates are being driven by “unshielding”, where some of the most vulnerable people have ed back to normal after two years of self-isolation. Dr Jenny Harries, chief executive of the UK Health Security Agency , told Sky News: These data confirm that cases have declined substantially following the peak of the Omicron wave.However, the increasing presence of the BA. sub-lineage of Omicron and the recent slight increase in infections in those over  show that the pandemic is not over and that we can expect to see COVID circulating at high levels.  Professor Paul Elliot, director of Imperial College Londonaposs React programme, said: At the moment, weaposre possibly seeing the beginning of an uptick, but we donapost know where itaposs going to go. Mark Woolhouse, professor of infectious disease epidemiology at the University of Edinburgh, said it was “impossible to make a sensible prediction” about the size of any BA. wave but the situation needed close monitoring.He told the: “The worry is that it’s hard to see anything happening in the next few weeks that will reverse the growth of BA. unless, that is, people decide on their own account to step up precautions.”Danny Altmann, professor of immunology at Imperial College, said the recent rise was foreseeable. “We’ll see a great deal more of this, along the lines of recent resurgent spikes in Scotland and Hong Kong,” he said. “Caseloads were by no means low or under control as we came out of all mitigations and, when you add in waning immunity and the enhanced transmissibility of BA., it looks like we are in for a dficult period, especially for the elderly.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSDepartment of HealthGrant ShappsHospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news hundreds-russian-made-items-removed-"Ukraine: Boris Johnson we will stop importing Russian oilByKate LallyTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Major supermarket chains in the UK have removed hundreds of Russian made products from their shelves in protest at the invasion of Ukraine.Asda, Sainsburyaposs, Aldi and Waitrose are among the stores that have taken a stand against Russia, with its actions in Ukraine having been widely condemned around the world. Sanctions have been imposed on a government level while companies have also inidually decided to stop their trade with Russian firms.It is thought that the boycott of Russian goods along with other economic sanctions could force Vladimir Putin into ending the invasion. Many major supermarkets have stopped selling Russian products, with some taking more signicant action than others, reported the Liverpool Echo. Tesco said it will not be removing any products from its shelves, but it will not place any further orders with Russian suppliers.A spokesperson for Tesco reportedly stated that it would no longer be “buying products from businesses that are wholly Russian-owned”. A statement from the supermarket read: “We are supporting humanitarian relief efforts through our partnerships with the Red Cross, food banks and other relief organisations to help those affected in Ukraine and neighbouring countries.” Here are all the products that have been removed from supermarkets: AsdaAsda has confirmed it is removing all products that originate from Russia from its stores and online - around  items in total.Most of these are spirits, though the list also includes fish and some sweets. Asda’s co-owner Mohsin Issa said: “We stand with our customers and colleagues who are shocked by the Russian invasion of Ukraine – and our thoughts are with those people whose lives are affected by this crisis.”On March , Asda and its charity, the Asda Foundation, announced a £m package to support displaced Ukrainian families in Europe and the UK. Aldi The budget-friendly retailer has said it will no longer sell Russian vodka.At the start of the month, Aldi announced that they would be making a donation to the Red Cross Ukraine Crisis Appeal.They said in a statement: We stand together with Aldi colleagues across the world and will be making a donation to the Red Cross Ukraine Crisis Appeal. After initially not confirming the donation amount, the supermarket confirmed they would be donating a further  million euros to established aid organisations to ensure help reaches those that need it most.  SainsburyapossProducts Sainsburyaposs have removed include the Russian Standard vodka and Karpayskiye black sunflower seeds.A Sainsbury’s spokesperson said: “We stand united with the people of Ukraine. We have reviewed our product range and have decided to remove from sale all products that are % sourced from Russia. The supermarket giant has also recently renamed its Chicken Kiev to Kyiv - the Ukrainian capital - to stand with Ukraine. Customers should see the change in packaging over the next few weeks.  Co-op, Morrisons and Waitrose The Co-op, Morrisons and Waitrose have also removed Russian vodka from their shelves. A spokesperson for the Co-op said the decision to remove the sale of Russian-made vodka was a sign of solidarity with the people of Ukraine. A spokesman for Morrisons, meanwhile, said: “We have taken action on our vodka lines today including delisting Russian Standard.” Waitrose and John Lewis said earlier this month they would no longer sell products made in Russia, starting with Russian vodka and one line of pizza oven pellets. title: inside worst hotel guests complain
story: Inside worst hotel where guests complain of filthy rooms with blood-stained duvetOther guests who stayed at The Airport Hotel in Manchester claim their bedding had not been changed for three weeks as the budget hotel is rated two out of five bubbles on TripAdvisorThis hotel in Manchester has left guests horried Image: Manchester Evening News WSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsGuests at an airport hotel have slammed the filthy rooms after finding what appears to be bloodstains on the bedding. Others who stayed at The Airport Hotel in Manchester claim there was a huge stench of cigarette smoke and alleged their bedding had not been changed for three weeks.The budget hotel has faced complaints from multiple guests online, and some have claimed that they found suspicious stains on a duvet and dirt throughout their bedroom, ManchesterEveningNews reports. The accommodation, which is rated two out of five bubbles on TripAdvisor, is owned by Britannia Hotels - which has recently been voted the worst hotel chain in the UK for the ninth year running.In recent weeks, a series of terrible reviews have been shared on the travel site, and guests at the Northenden hotel branch branded it diabolical and filthy. One guest, named Emma, claimed that she had been staying in the hotel after fleeing domestic abuse. Rating the hotel just one star, she wrote: Cleaning staff haven’t changed my bedding in THREE WEEKS actually think I’m going to be sick from how they’ve treated me. Another, named Laura alleged she had an awful experience where she found herself sinking right through the mattress through to the other side. Laura claimed that after she changed rooms three times she ended up in one with stained bedding. She said: Given room  and wanted a little sleep. Pulled back the duvet and the bed springs were coming through the mattress so we were given another room on the same floor. I sat on the bed and sunk through it! It jolted my back really badly. I took a picture of the mattress to show the manager.  Was given a third room and the manager came with us and again a mattress with the springs sowingthrough. He admitted that all the mattresses in the hotel were in the same sorry state. So I asked for spare duvets to sleep on to try to create padding from springs. One of the spare duvets had blood on it! I then got the spare pillows down and they had hairs all over them from a previous guest. Also there were chocolate buttons under my bed and a chupa cup wrapper under my friendaposs bed. Certainly not cleaned. Putting hygiene sticker on the door make no dferenceyou do not vacuum the floor! She also claims that she woke up in the morning with terrible back pain and was forced to lie on the dirty floor to try and relieve it. Another guest, Catherine B, said it was the worst hotel she has ever stayed in. She said: Our allocated room was an unprepared room that had not been cleaned, it had dirty sheets on the bed that had clearly been slept in and mud on the carpet. This was rectied, but our subsequent room was dreadful. The mattress had springs you could feel through the sheets, and the edge of the mattress had collapsed. The whole hotel is worn out and everything needs replacing. The lts smell of stale cigarette smoke. The whole place has an unpleasant odour, possibly due to the smoking rooms, and cigarette smoke infiltrating the whole building. Avoid at all costs. Another user, Aidan, included pictures of a stained door handle and a stain on the floor, saying: Honestly, DO NOT STAY HERE! Rooms are filthy, unfit for purpose and theyaposre just an absolute joke all around. The lts look like they haven’t been replaced since the s. The hotel, which is only three miles from Manchester Airport, has , reviews, with more than , of these being apospoorapos or aposterribleapos and only  being aposexcellentapos. Consumer watchdog Which  ranked it at the bottom of a league table of  large hotel chains. The survey of , hotel guests over  months to October , left Britannia with just  points out of a possible . Despite this, not everyone has had a bad experience at the Airport Hotel, with one recent guest saying it was absolutely fine. One read: Our room was fine. Clean, warm and quite spacious actually but the bed was a bit old and uncomfortable. Other than that itaposs dficult for us to really find fault. We had a burger and chips from the bar which was perfectly edible and we only stayed in the room for just over  hours. Itaposs not The Ritz and the room decor was a bit tired but for our purposes, the Britannia was absolutely fine. Another recent review added: Perfect for our needs for an early flight from Manchester airport! The room is cleana little basic but plenty space for our family! The reception staff are very friendly and efficient and the bar very welcoming! Suited our needs perfectly! Great value for airport parking too! Thecontacted Britannia Hotels for comment. news uk-news kate-middleton-shed-tear-wedding-"Kate Middletons wedding dress revisitedByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments It may have been a grand wedding with almost , guests packed into Westminster Abbey for the service, but the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge managed to make the historical day a very personal one. Kate had her sister Pippa as her maid of honour while Prince William chose his younger brother Prince Harry as his best man.Harry kept up best man tradition by giving a speech at the wedding reception - and according to many of the guests it was the highlight of the big day, evenhe did make Kate cry. Royal author Katie Nicholl gave an insight into the tear-jerking speech in her biography Harry: Le, Loss, and Love.  She said: It was affectionate, warm and funny and touched William deeply. The speech was peppered with Harryaposs classic sense of humour, and he ribbed his brother: aposWilliam didnapost have a romantic bone in his body before he met Kate, so I knew it was serious when William suddenly started cooing down the phone at Kateapos. Famous for his mimicry, Harry then impersonated his brother calling Kate aposBabykinsapos, to much laughter from the guests. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. When he said the couple’s decade-long romance was his inspiration, there was a shy smile from Chelsy, while Kate shed a tear. Kate and brother-in-law Harry previously had a jovial relationship - he even famously described Kate as the sister he never had and the pair were often seen giggling or sharing a joke at royal events.But according to royal expert Duncan Larcombe, Harry and Kateaposs sibling-like relationship is now long in the past.  It comes amid a growing feud between William and Harry and the fact that Harry and we Meghan Markle decided to quit as royals and leave the UK for Calornia. And speaking earlier this year as Kate approached her th birthday, Duncan told OK! : Kate was, as Harry said, the sister he never had and clearly that is not the case anymore.There was a time when Harry would have been instrumental in any celebrations or any fun that the couple were having, but those days are long in the past. title: kate middleton urged stop trying
story: Kate Middleton urged to stop trying to be like Princess Diana by royal expertA royal journalist took to Twitter to share her thoughts after a never-before-seen shot of Diana, Princess of Wales, caused many people to point out similarities with Kate MiddletonKate Middleton was urged to stick to being herself Image: ©Francis Dias NEWSPIX INTERNATIONALByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |comments The Duchess of Cambridge has been urged not to try to be like Princess Diana, by a royal expert.Similarities between the pair were highlighted by many royal fans online after a never-seen-before picture of the Princess of Wales emerged. The portrait, taken by esteemed photographer David Bailey in , captured a black and white side profile of the princess. Sheaposs posed in a satin one-shoulder dress, which has been paired with a teardrop earring as she looked off into the distance.This has been compared with some of the portraits released of Kate on her th birthday earlier this year, where she too can be seen wearing a similar style gown and looking away from the camera.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Royal biographer Angela Levin took to Twitter to share her thoughts on the comparisons being made by royal fans, stating that the Duchess doesnapost need to emulate Diana.She wrote: “I think Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge should stick to being herself. She doesnapost need to try to be someone  including Diana. Sheaposs great as she is.” The tweet sparked discussion among royal fans, who were quick to also share their thoughts.One person said: I donapost even think she is trying to be Diana, I donapost see any major similarities to Diana apart from the fact that they are both beautul and kind. The Duchess of Cambridge never tried to be anyone  but herself, wrote another. She has been in the public eye for over  years. A lot longer than that of Diana. The Duchess of Cambridge has made her own mark and done things her own way including creating her adorable family. A third commented: Of course she canapost be compared to Diana. Diana was doing over  appearances every year, and so many tours and she was so young. She had a huge influence on pop culture and her Charity work remains unmatched. So yeah. No comparison. While someone  put: Spot on Angela! Nor is she trying to be anyone . It’s certain people pushing that nonsense.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: miracle baby born 23 weeks
story: Miracle baby born at  weeks with % chance of survival finally goes homeLucas Chialton-Helliar was the size of a "biro pen" when he was delivered at just  weeks at LiverpoolWomens Hospital, with doctors warning the tot had a % chance of survivalSarah Chialton said Lucas is doing really well after being discharged from hospitalByOlivia WilliamsMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A miracle baby who was born at just  weeks and had a % chance of survival has finally made it home. Lucas Chialton-Helliar was the size of a biro pen when he was delivered at Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital in October last year.Mum Sarah Chialton found out she was going into early labour after telling doctors about a small amount of aposunusual dischargeapos she had noticed.Sarah, from Litherland, Merseyside, went into hospital to get examined and was told she was already dilated, the Liverpool Echo reports.The -year-old said: I was  weeks pregnant and I was in work and I noticed - because I am a nurse myself - I noticed a little bit of unusual discharge. So I rang the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital up and they told me to come in to get examined.They thought it was down to a water infection at the time. So I went into the Womenaposs, got examined and they said I was cm dilated. Sarah was going into early labour and doctors told her thather baby was to survive delivery, there was only a % survival rate in the first few weeks of his le. The mum added: That was at  weeks and one day, so they were going through scenarios with me. They said a  week baby doesnapost have a good outcome basically.  Doctors were saying it was a % chance of survival in the first couple of weeksthe baby was to survive delivery. Lucas came into the world weighing lb oz at  weeks and four days and Sarah said he was the size of a biro pen.The baby boy went through a lot during his  day stay in hospital, including six dferent infections, sepsis, two collapsed lungs and several blood transfusions.Lucas was discharged from Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital on Sunday, March , when he was four months old.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Sarah and her family described Lucas as a miracle and the -year-old wanted to thank staff at the neonatal unit at Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. She said: I want to praise the neonatal unit at the Womenaposs because they have just been amazing through this. The nurses, the doctors have all been amazing. Sarah said her placenta was sent off for tests to look into why she went into early labour but the results left doctors unsure as to why she did. The -year-old said Lucas is now doing really well since being discharged from hospital at the weekend and is currently on home oxygen. He now weighs lbs. She said: Lucas is doing well, really well. Heaposs taking feeds and bottles as well. Heaposs brilliant, heaposs doing really well. Sarah said she wanted to share her story to thank staff at Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital and to help other mums who might be going through something similar. The nurse said she wanted mums going through the same thing to know there is aposlight at the end of it. news uk-news moment-biker-screams-you-nearly-"Liverpool: CCTV captures man jump on car bonnet after incident in ChildwallByEllen KirwinAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsThis is the moment a masked vandal was caught on camera smashing a Range Rover and screaming you nearly killed me after a crash. The collision, which involved a motorbike and a Nissan, happened in Liverpool on Wednesday at about .pm.Afterwards, the motorbike was reportedly left in the middle of the road in flames after the rider ran off from the scene, LiverpoolEcho reports. Jake Carter, from Childwall, has shared Ring doorbell footage and a CCTV clip of what happened on his TikTok page after the crash happened outside his home. The -year-old claims the Silver Nissan, which was hit by the scrambler bike, belonged to a mechanic who was coming to his home to look at a car.  He claims the mechanic indicated and drove towards his house and onto his drive. However, he claims that as the driver turned into the driveway, two scrambler bikes flew up the road and smacked into the back of the Nissan. Ring doorbell footage shows one of the riders jumping on his wall and screaming: You nearly killed me lad. What were you doing   In footage shared with the ECHO, a masked person wearing a balaclava can then be seen jumping onto the bonnet of a Range Rover on the drive and smashing it with his foot. The Range Rover was not involved in the crash. Speaking over the TikTok video, which shows the CCTV footage, Jake Carter said: Three lads wearing balaclavas were extremely confrontational and aggressive to the gentleman.  The mechanic is an older guy who is lovely and he was extremely shook up [sic] by this situation. But then one of the three musketeers decides to do a little bit of a jigg on the wall before jumping onto my dadaposs car and basically kicked the windscreen in. Spiderman then jumps back on the wall before fleeing the scene on another scrambler. Jakeaposs video of the crash and the thug later vandalising his dadaposs car has been viewed on TikTok more than , times.  It was shared on his page @Jakecartermusic with the caption: Help us find who these scumbags are, someone must know something  They’re missing a scrambler now! Please share. In the video, Jake points to the ECHO article about the motorbike being left abandoned in the middle of the road. He then says: So this happened outside our house in Liverpool today and one lovely boy decided to do some bodywork to my dadaposs Jeep. Police confirmed they are aware of the incident and are appealing for information. No one was injured in the incident but both the Nissan and Range Rover were damaged.A spokesperson for Mersyside police said: We are appealing for information following a report a motorbike was on fire in Childwall this afternoon .At around .pm emergency services were called to a report that a motorbike was on fire in the middle of the road on Childwall Park Avenue, near to the Black Woods. Three males were then reported to have been seen riding off on motorbikes towards Woolton Village. There are no reports of anyone injured during the incident. Two cars, a Nissan and a Range Rover, were reported to have been damaged near to the incident. We are appealing for any witnesses, CCTV and dash camera footage which may assist the investigation.Anyone with information on this incident is asked to contact @MerPolCC on Twitter or ‘ Merseyside Police Contact Centre’ on Facebook with reference  of  March.Any one with information about the use or storage of weapons can DM @MerPolCC or @CrimestoppersUK on   . title: mum who delivered parcels extra
story: Mum who delivered parcels for extra cash quits day job now earning £, a weekAtlanta Martin, , quickly settled into her side-hustle as a delivery driver which she fit around her day job at Gatwick Airport and now earns £, a weekAtlanta Martin, , has turned her side-hustle into a flexible and lucrative careerByCharlotte Penketh-KingLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA hardworking mum who started delivering packages to make a bit of extra cash has been able to quit her day job after discovering she can earn a whopping £, a week.Atlanta Martin, , was working as a flight dispatcher at Gatwick Airport when she decided to take on another role three years ago. She quickly settled on being a delivery driver, which she could fit around her current hours at the airport and soon realised how lucrative her second job could be.The mum-of-one, from Worthing, West Sussex, did so well that she eventually decided to quit her day job after two years. She can now rake in up to a grand a week by putting in -hour days and is able to plan her schedule around her two-year-old daughter.  And the profit she has made from the delivery job is enough to fund a nice lestyle, including a recent trip to Disney World in Florida. Atlanta said: Iaposm really happy I made the decision to do this job full time. With delivering, I can choose my own hours, work as much as I wish too and earn the same money or more. It was a risk as delivering is self employed and the money is not guaranteed, but I have no regrets and it is working really well.  Atlanta worked at Gatwick prior to giving birth and realised that she could make extra money by delivering while on maternity leave. She said: I worked there for three and a half years but I have a daughter who is coming up to three years old. The hours I had to work and the sht pattern was not flexible enough at the airport. I started delivering whilst on my maternity leave as an extra form of income. Thanks to the flexibility of delivering, I found I could work the hours I wanted to around my daughter. I started posting videos of me delivering on my social media which did really well so I decided to leave my full time job so I could pursue delivering and growing my social media channels.  Since ditching the airport job, Atlanta has been putting in the hours working on her own time delivering in the car for Just Eat, Uber Eats, Deliveroo and Beelivery. She starts as early as am and works until as late as :pm - racking up around  deliveries on a busy day. Her hard work has been worth it as sheaposs been raking in the cash, making up to £, a week through delivering across the south east of England. Between February  and February  alone, she earned £. from Just Eat, £. from UberEats, £. from Deliveroo and £. from Beelivery, as well as £ in cash tips - totalling at an impressive £. in just one week.  Atlanta was amazed by the amount of money sheaposs been making alongside her boyfriend, Benjamin Hasker, , who also works as a delivery driver as well as a magician and doing Punch and Judy shows. The mum has no plans toto the airline industry and is thrilled with her new career. She said: Itaposs not guaranteed to be £, every week - the more hours you put in, the more you earn. Thanks to my hard work earning this amount of money, myself, my daughter and my partner all went to Disney World, Florida, for two weeks in December  . This was my daughteraposs first ever holiday. I have already bought two cars outright in the time that I have been delivering for work. I havenapost bought anything for my daughteraposs third birthday yet as it is in June, but we are planning to go to London for the weekend for a trip to London Zoo. Iaposm really happy I chose to pursue this as a full time career. It was a risk but I have no regrets. title: ordinary three bed terraced home
story: Ordinary three-bed terraced home hides incredible PALACE in living roomThe terraced home with  bedrooms is located in Christchurch, Dorset and was listed on the market on TuesdayA -bedroom property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,ByRuaraidh GilmourLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |commentsA three-bed property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,. The terraced home in Christchurch, Dorset was listed on the market on Tuesday March . The large living room takes up over half of the downstairs and its main feature is a detailed ceiling painting that depicts angels flying and sitting on clouds. The depiction is bordered with round gold and blue trim with ious patterns.  A bust of a woman stands tall at the back of the room, while gold trimmed patterned chairs and couches are positioned next to the light blue walls. There is a marble coffee table that sits on an old fashioned royal-looking carpet whilst a large gold rimmed mirror hangs on the back wall. Breaking the Roman theme, there is a flat screen TV hung from the wall and a guitar amplier resting on one of the chairs.  Leaving the lavish room, the rest of the house appears to be far more common. The kitchen is of a good size and has a double glass door that leads to the garden. Two of the three bedrooms are of good size and can comfortably accommodate double beds, while the third room could only fit a single bed.  The only bathroom in the property is situated upstairs and has a large bath and a separate shower. In their listing on Rightmove, Goadsby, who are managing the property wrote: A spacious terraced home situated in a popular area being just yards from Two Riversmeet Leisure Centre with its golf course. Christchurch town centre is also easily accessible.  There is a covered entrance porch which has a storage cupboard, a door leads through to the lounge. The lounge is a good size with a front aspect window. A door leads through to the kitchen breakfast room which has ample space for a dining table whilst also having a good range of wall and floor cupboards with working surfaces over... There are  doubles, both having fitted cupboards and Bedroom  is currently used as an office.  The bathroom benefits from a corner bath with separate shower cubicle, pedestal wash hand basin and low level w.c. One social media user saw the unique living room and decided to share it on Reddit: For just £k you can enjoy the wonders of the Sistine Chapel from the comfort of your own living room. The post has over  likes and has been commented on over a dozen times.Reddit users found the living room amusing.@Grumpyandproud said: I was not prepared for that living room. @Keiepse wrote: aposThe lounge is a good size with a front aspect window.aposAmazing that the agent couldnapost think of anything  for the description. @Leftpillz commented: Itaposs a pretty appropriate design given the cityaposs name, Christchurch. @Nicowltan replied: That living room is insane, but Iaposm a big fan of the dog at the back door.@busyphil added: Wow. I love the way the description doesnapost reference that ceiling at all.
